Automatic Voter Registration is the catalyst Nevada needs to bring voter registration into the 21st Century

Dear ##SM_RULE_360 Email Salutation##,

Nevada has a voter participation problem: Thousands upon thousands of eligible voters are not even registered.

But we can take a huge step toward changing that by supporting Question 5, the Automatic Voter Registration Initiative, in November. The ACLU of Nevada is throwing its full support behind the measure.

Voting YES on Question 5 means that your voter registration will be updated automatically when you go to the DMV. If you’re new to Nevada, you will be registered to vote automatically.

The numbers show we have a voter participation problem in Nevada: In 2016, the U.S. Census Bureau estimated the state is home to 2.1 million eligible voters, suggesting nearly half a million voters aren’t registered.

Learn More

A Pew survey suggests less than 20 percent of Americans have been offered to register to vote at the DMV. And NPR reported that less than 5 percent of Las Vegans under 30 in participated in the 2016 elections.

We know Automatic Voter Registration will make it easier for those young people to register and vote. It will also help first-time voters, communities of color, people serving in the military, rural residents. It will make life a little easier for everyone that uses the DMV. And those who do not want to want vote can easily opt-out.

Question 5 is the catalyst Nevada needs to modernize our voter registration systems. Put simply: Making it easier to vote is good for our democracy.

For more information about Nevadans for Secure Elections and Question 5, please visit nvsecureelections.com.

Thanks for sticking with us,

Tod Story
Executive Director, ACLU of Nevada
